chapter.title: Upgrading Basics
chapter.para: This chapter shows you how to upgrade OpenAM core services. Starting with OpenAM 10.0.0 and later versions, OpenAM supports schema changes as part of an upgrade, so you may need to run the upgrade wizard at the end of the upgrade process. The wizard will automatically write all necessary changes to the configuration store and will prompt you to restart the container.

There are two ways to upgrade your deployment: using the defaults and adding the customized files. You should try the default upgrade in a test environment before you apply it to a production environment. ForgeRock also recommends working on the customized version in a test environment before updating a productions version so that you will be aware of any potential issues that you may encounter with your customized version.

note.para: ForgeRock strongly recommend that you do not expose an OpenAM instance to users during the upgrade process since running the wizard does not require authorization.

procedure.title: To Upgrade From OpenAM 9.1 Or Later
procedure.para: ForgeRock has considerably simplified OpenAM core services upgrade with respect to earlier versions. If you have one instance that is OpenAM 9.1 or later, these steps will walk you through adding your customized content into the deployable .war file and upgrading to the next version of OpenAM.

step.para: Verify that the JAVA_HOME is properly set.
Backup the file system directory for the current deployment.
If you have multiple instances deployed, all instances must be running when you backup.
If you have multiple instances deployed, all instances must be running when you backup.
Export the configuration backend/DN from the directory server.
Stop OpenAM, or if necessary to redeploy OpenAM, stop the container where OpenAM is running.
If you have multiple instance, you will need to deploy the upgrade .war file for all of your OpenAM instances.

For the first instance, follow the instructions in the upgrade wizard if you are applying upgrades to OpenAM 10.0.0 or later. If you prefer, you can use the upgrade.jar from the command line to complete the upgrade process.
If you downloaded the .zip file to upgrade the tools, reinstall them.
If OpenAM is running in a site deployment with multiple servers, configure your load balancer to take the OpenAM server out of the site pool during upgrade.

example.title: Upgrading to OpenAM 10.0.0
example.para: The following example upgrades OpenAM 9.5.5 to OpenAM 10.0.0 on an Ubuntu instance using Apache Tomcat. The example only addresses the .war file. Review the Installation Guide to reinstall the tools following a successful upgrade.
Your port numbers and directory names may be different than the ones used in the example. Also, make sure to use your password where applicable.
If you have multiple instances, make sure they are all running during the backup process.

listitem.para: Verify that the JAVA_HOME is properly set.

listitem.screen: $ cd /path/to/ssoadm-home/openam/bin $ ./ssoadm export -svc-cfg --adminid amadmin --password-file path/to/password/file --encryptsecret mySeretEncryptionKey --outfile openam-config-export.xml

listitem.para: Export the configuration backend/DN from the directory server.

listitem.screen:
$ cd /path/to/tomcat $ ./bin/shutdown.sh
Password: Using CATALINA_BASE: /path/to/tomcat Using CATALINA_HOME: /path/to/tomcat Using CATALINA_TMPDIR: /path/to/tomcat/temp Using JRE_HOME: /path/to/jdk1.6/jre Using CLASSPATH: /path/to/tomcat/bin/bootstrap.jar
$ cd /path/to/tomcat/webapps $ rm -rf openam $ rm openam.war $ rm -rf /path/to/tomcat/work/Catalina/localhost/openam $ cp /path/to/expanded-openam-war/upgrade-war/openam.war .

listitem.para: In your browser, go to your instance of OpenAM and follow the instructions in the upgrade wizard.

textobject.para: The initial upgrade screen lets you choose to upgrade or to restore the configuration.
The initial upgrade screen lets you choose to upgrade or to restore the configuration.

listitem.para: Reinstall any tools you would like to have with the upgraded version of OpenAM. Refer to the Installation Guide if you are unsure how to reinstall the tools.
If OpenAM is running in a site deployment with multiple servers, configure your load balancer to take the OpenAM server out of the site pool during upgrade.

example.para: Once you have verified that the deployment is complete, you can go back and delete the directories your created to expand the .war files.
